wordPressPost.title: 10 Habits Most Women Don’t Know are Bad for their Skin
wordPressPost.content:
The skin is the largest organ in the human body, it is also our protective shield and it has the ability to absorb up to 60-70% of whatever we place onto it! So, taking care of your skin and being extra careful with the products you use is important. So, think for a second why nicotine patches are recommended for smokers who want to quit smoking? It gets absorbed better, faster and, actually, transdermal nicotine replacement therapy can be a very effective way to help them quit smoking.

The Skin

The skin has many functions related to the muscles and bones. It is made of three layers: the epidermis that acts like a waterproof barrier, the dermis under the epidermis that contains tough connective tissues, hair follicles, and sweat glands, and the deeper layer called subcutaneous tissue or the hypodermis.

10 Major Contributors To Poor Skin Health

  • High alcohol consumption

Too much alcohol  can provoke a loss of skin elasticity; as alcohol robs the body of many nutrients and can cause a toxic liver. The result is poor skin health.

  • Excessive exposure to sunlight

Too much sun exposure allows UV rays to penetrate your inner skin layers, something that can cause cell damage and cancer! Yikes!

  • Too much simple carb and sugar in the diet

High sugar and carb consumption can malnutrition Certain nutrients are vital to the skin such as vitamin C and Collagen, resulting in Wrinkles.

  • Dehydration

Dehydration can cause the skin to look “rougher.” Not consuming enough water can create havoc by reducing the amount of toxins excreted by the kidneys as the body tries to conserve energy and water, causing urination to decrease. Therefore, all the toxicity buildup stays in the body; the body then robs the skin of its moisture to keep hydrated.

  • Unhealthy fats

It is no longer a secret that many fatty foods such as fried foods which contain a lot of tran-saturated fats can increase poor skin health.

  • The use of many products at once or chemical based products

Having lots of creams, lotion and makeup on your skin stop it from breathing well, causing the sebaceous gland to get blocked. The sebaceous gland is responsible for secreting oily substances that help to lubricate our skin and hairs, and when this gland is blocked, cyst or acne can form.

  • Application hair products, gel, or oil,

Whether the products melt and run down, especially around your face or any part of the body, can be the beginning of skin problems; application of too many hair products can also increase bacterial activity, resulting in many other skin ailments.

  • Poor hygiene

Sweating is a part of the natural cleansing system of the body, but when you sweat over and over in the same clothes and wear them over and over without washing them it becomes a habitat for poor bacteria. As for the face, using the same pillowcase over and over without washing can be very detrimental, as the oils, skin dirt, etc. can be rubbed on your face over and over again, night in night out.

  • Skin washing

We are living in an era where most companies making beauty products want women to feel that they have to use their products in order to look better, which is not the case.

  • Stress

Stress is a part of our daily lives, but it affects some people at a deeper level, causing anxiety, hormonal imbalance and many physical and emotional issues. It’s best to change your lifestyle.

You can help your skin by avoiding simple carbohydrate and sugar, unhealthy fats and excess alcohol. You can also use essential oils, herbs, and skin brushing to help your skin.

Herbs and Remedies That Can Help Prevent Skin Problems

  • Aloe vera

Aloe vera can help decreasing the occurrence of acne and heals the skin.

  • Witch hazel extract

Can be effective in treating blocked sebaceous gland, and controlling oil secretion thus, preventing cysts and acne from forming.

  • Calendula cream

Calendula may help eliminating the blemishes associated with Acne without any scarring.

  • Evening Primrose Oil

GLA can help with mood probelms, PMS, menopause and acne. PMS is due to hormonal imbalance that contributes to skin problems.

  • Methylsulfonylmethane or MSM 

MSM is an organic sulfur-containing compound that can help improve immune function and decrease inflammation.

Essential Oils

Tea Tree and lavender essential oil applied topically can improve the appearance of the lesions caused by acne and reduce inflammation of the skin.

Herbal teas

Burdock root and dandelion root tea can alleviate acne, cleanse the body of unwanted toxins and add extra glow to the skin.

Nutrition

Eat well by increasing fruits, vegetables and anti-inflammatory spices, and seeds in your life. You can also try meditating, doing yoga or going for a walk.

Note:

For better support, you can do a liver cleanse made of a combination of herbs; this can also affect the appearance of the skin as it removes impurities that contribute to many skin conditions. For more benefits, you can also try using castor oil pack applied topically to the liver area to remove toxins and help rejuvenating the liver.
